topic: Recommendation Systems: Collaborative, Content-Based, and Knowledge-Based Filtering
summary: This session introduces recommendation systems, a subclass of information filtering systems that predict user preferences for items. Recommendation algorithms are categorized into collaborative filtering, content-based, and knowledge-based approaches. Collaborative filtering relies on user responses to items, while content-based filtering uses item features. Collaborative filtering is further divided into neighborhood-based (user-based and item-based) and model-based algorithms. User-based filtering recommends items based on similar users' preferences, while item-based filtering recommends items similar to those a user has already chosen. Content-based filtering recommends items based on the similarity of item features to a user's past favorites. The session details the steps for user-based and item-based filtering, including calculating user similarity using Jaccard, cosine, Euclidean, and Pearson distances, and computing user interest in items.

Hello everyone, I am Haiying Che, from Institute of Data Science and knowledge Engineering

In this chapter, we introduced some useful platform， Spark MLlib and TensorFlow.
And in this session, we will talk about a typical big data analysis application, Recommendation System
A recommendation system is a subclass of Information filtering Systems that seeks to predict the rating or the preference a user might give to an item.
In simple words, it is an algorithm that suggests relevant items to users. Recommendation system is widely used in many fields, like Netflex, Amazon, JD, TaoBao
QQ music etc.
Recommendation Algorithms can be roughly divided into 3 categories. Collaborative filtering, content based and knowledge based. And the big difference between Collaborative filtering algorithm and content-based algorithm is that content based algorithm relies on the item features themselves, but the Collaborative filtering relies on how other user respond to the same item.
Collaborative filtering can be further divided into Neighborhood-based and model based, neighborhood-based algorithm includes user-based and item-based algorithm, and we will discuss in this session. Model based algorithms include Latent Factor model, Graph model and others. In latent Factor model, I will use matrix factorization as example to explain.
The content-based recommendation algorithm recommends items based on item features, which include structured features and unstructured features.
And the third category is knowledge-based algorithms.

In user-based filtering, we find the similar users based on the common items they chose before,

In item-based filtering, we define the Ice cream with Egg Roll and ice cream cone as similar items based on the user chosen behavior,

Content-based Filtering Recommendations, is the first recommendation algorithm that recommends items similar to a user's past favorite items.
The key here is the measure of item similarity, which is the core of the algorithm application process.
Three main steps:
Item Representation: extracting some features (content) for each item to represent them
Profile Learning: Using the feature data of a user's past favorite (or not favorite) items to learn the user's preference features (that is user’s profile)
Recommendation Generation: By comparing the user profile obtained in the previous step with the features of the candidate items, a set of items with the highest relevance is recommended to this user.
